reviewText:
It's an interesting concept and all, but the game wasn't designed very well.

For one, the game doesn't look that good. The animations are a little dull, and a palette of 6 colors doesn't leave much room for creativity. While I understand the reason for the choice, It's just boring to look at. The colors also mean that the walls you control disappear entirely when you get rid of them, which leads to annoying and unneccesary trial and error. You know where to go, you jump, you have no reference as to where you are in the jump, you cross your fingers and bring back the walls, and you clip into the wall, dying.
The game would have worked much better if the obstacles faded out instead of disappeared.

Two, the various RNG and practically unavoidable obsticles. Like the idea of objects randomly popping in front of you, leaving you no time to react? Do you like the method to get rid of them to be randomized. This happens TONS in this game, and it is extremely annoying having to constantly die and start over to get around them. A puzzle game shouldn't have you rely on luck.
Oh, and the hitboxes kinda suck too, and there are times when you can completely skip over areas.

Three, the game expects you to be psychic. There are far too many instances of the game putting the path out of your viewing range, forcing you to jump over a put to find out where to go. There are also cases where you fall down and have to dodge blades, and again, not knowing where they are and where to land. Not. Fun.

Four, the music. 1 track, looping over and over and over. The game is far too long to have just 1 track, especially with the constant retrying that you will have to do. Same for the SFX, as you are going to have to listen to the same jump grunt every single time you jump. Very repetitive.

Five, the story. He is blind, was sent to hell or something, and now controls colors for some reason. That's pretty much it.

There are also various other issues, such as the sometimes unresponsive controls and the weird health mechanic, but those are minor issues IMO.


In the end, I think it's a good concept, but poorly executed and just not fun to play. Unless you have some fetish with the color control concept, there isn't really a reason for you to play this. I wish I could say better, but it's not a game that anyone should bother playing.

reviewText: I really like the ideas this game has. While the story wasn't enough to hook me in the little I played, Simply switching the background to change the visibility and tangibility of platforms and enemies is a very creative idea. Unfortunately, the game itself leaves a lot to be desired, particularly how the game handles collisions.\nIn most games, if you jump toward a ceiling, you'll hit your head but that's it. In this game you bounce off the ceiling. When you jump toward a wall, you sort of clip into it/get stuck on it for a moment, and then go shooting off with more momentum than you should have in a different direction. If you don't time your jumps right, you'll find yourself falling down and having to try again, often for something it feels like you couldn't have prevented. I was ok with the collision problem and willing to look past it, but the thing that ruined the game for me was the way that the game handles platform spawning. Basically, when you chenge the background to the same color as a platform, it dissapears and the game despawns it, only to respawn it when you change the color again. Because of this, it's possible to tele-frag yourself with your own platforms, often entirely by accident. And instead of pushing you out of it, or even cutting your health in half like using a special move does(!), the game insta-kills you and makes you restart the level. Since you don't know a platform is there until you change the background away from its color, it's very easy to kill yourself this way -- in fact an early level requires you to time your fall between to platforms you can't see and respawn them with you're between them. If you go too high or too low, you insta-die. It's very frustrating and something I can't look past.\nAlthogether, Color Symphony is a good idea for a game undone by shoddy execution.

It's an interesting concept and all, but the game wasn't designed very well.

For one, the game doesn't look that good. The animations are a little dull, and a palette of 6 colors doesn't leave much room for creativity. While I understand the reason for the choice, It's just boring to look at. The colors also mean that the walls you control disappear entirely when you get rid of them, which leads to annoying and unneccesary trial and error. You know where to go, you jump, you have no reference as to where you are in the jump, you cross your fingers and bring back the walls, and you clip into the wall, dying.
The game would have worked much better if the obstacles faded out instead of disappeared.

Two, the various RNG and practically unavoidable obsticles. Like the idea of objects randomly popping in front of you, leaving you no time to react? Do you like the method to get rid of them to be randomized. This happens TONS in this game, and it is extremely annoying having to constantly die and start over to get around them. A puzzle game shouldn't have you rely on luck.
Oh, and the hitboxes kinda suck too, and there are times when you can completely skip over areas.

Three, the game expects you to be psychic. There are far too many instances of the game putting the path out of your viewing range, forcing you to jump over a put to find out where to go. There are also cases where you fall down and have to dodge blades, and again, not knowing where they are and where to land. Not. Fun.

Four, the music. 1 track, looping over and over and over. The game is far too long to have just 1 track, especially with the constant retrying that you will have to do. Same for the SFX, as you are going to have to listen to the same jump grunt every single time you jump. Very repetitive.

reviewText: I really like the ideas this game has. While the story wasn't enough to hook me in the little I played, Simply switching the background to change the visibility and tangibility of platforms and enemies is a very creative idea. Unfortunately, the game itself leaves a lot to be desired, particularly how the game handles collisions.\nIn most games, if you jump toward a ceiling, you'll hit your head but that's it. In this game you bounce off the ceiling. When you jump toward a wall, you sort of clip into it/get stuck on it for a moment, and then go shooting off with more momentum than you should have in a different direction. If you don't time your jumps right, you'll find yourself falling down and having to try again, often for something it feels like you couldn't have prevented. I was ok with the collision problem and willing to look past it, but the thing that ruined the game for me was the way that the game handles platform spawning. Basically, when you chenge the background to the same color as a platform, it dissapears and the game despawns it, only to respawn it when you change the color again. Because of this, it's possible to tele-frag yourself with your own platforms, often entirely by accident. And instead of pushing you out of it, or even cutting your health in half like using a special move does(!), the game insta-kills you and makes you restart the level. Since you don't know a platform is there until you change the background away from its color, it's very easy to kill yourself this way -- in fact an early level requires you to time your fall between to platforms you can't see and respawn them with you're between them. If you go too high or too low, you insta-die. It's very frustrating and something I can't look past.\nAlthogether, Color Symphony is a good idea for a game undone by shoddy execution.

reviewText:
TLDR at the bottom of the review

Color Symphony is a puzzle-platformer where you can change between 3 colored background, changing to one of the colored background will dematerialize all the elements of this color while materializing the 2 others colors.
You play as a vampire/dark elf/something who got blinded (literally) by his friend(s) and send to hell (which is apparently a large USA city in black and white). The plot of the game is to go back to your friend(s) for revenge. He forgive them and continue their dreams? for no reason
In each level, you need to go to the door to get to the next level and you will be facing colored eagle, dog with 2 heads,  tentacles and sawblades you can mask them by changing to their colors. The first levels are easy enough, even if you get hit because you have a regenerating health bar. You also have an ability which use like 60% of your health to be able to combine all 3 colors to hide all colored obstacles but it's really useless because you switch colors all the time and you need to wait for the ability to wear off and the only time you really need to use it are too obvious (like 3 differents colored sawblades or tentacles on top of each other or in a row) making this skill worthless.

After a while, the levels become more difficult but still challenging until the worst idea in a video game : Colored sawblade that appear when you are near them, which make the invisible coin block from Super Mario World like a blessing to play with because they are often located in the air, right above a bottomless pit, right before the exit, which mean you have to jump, get hit and die because you weren't expecting it and that not the worst, that would be too easy, you just need to come back and switch to the color of the sawblade to go through, right? Well no because their colors are randomised every time you got near them, so you need to be on your toes and press the right color because there is a slight delay before you can switch again and by that time, you would see your character get hit with a big recoil Castlevania/Megaman style where you can do nothing before you land and going in the bottomless pit and wait 2-3 seconds before your character die in it before you get the continue screen.

If you didn't stop here (I wish I did), the level design become more and more dickish with the introduction of leap of faith through a vertical shaft with sawblade you cannot touch or you will go flying into a pit, or where you can't see the platform and have to guess where it's going to be.

IF you didn't stop here (I mean, come on, it's like platformers have regress with this), you will have to do pixel perfect jump on 8 pixels girders with your character's hitbox of 4 pixels wide which is right in the empty space between your shoes.

IF YOU DIDN'T STOP HERE (We are back to bad NES games with this), you will have to jump into a colored inclosed box, which mean you have to jump into it, select the color of the box making it invisible, pray you get into the box and switch back to an another color to make the box solid again and if a pixel of you is inside an object, you get one-shot, even if you have all your life. Also, those boxes love to have sawblade on their side, making it more hard and less fun.

IF YOU DIDN'T STOP HERE (What is wrong with you?), you will have a final level with a cathedral on the background, no enemies, no jump to do, only go right, have a line of monologue and you get treated to a 5 images credits with reuse pictures from the intro, making it one of the worst credits I have ever see.

In conclusion, this game had a kinda neat idea gameplay-wise, but run out of idea to work with it and made the game really frustating to finish. The music (There is only two tracks, one during gameplay and one during the credits) is meh, not bad enough to want to mute the audio but not good enough to put it on my MP3. I also wonder why this game is on Steam when it's obviously a flash game you see on various websites.

TLDR : This game is basically a flash game you find on Newgrounds or Armor Games, play for 5-10 minutes and have a good impression of it or try to beat it and see all the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t level design and wish you didn't played this game.

reviewText:
This game is a puzzle like platformer that involves a world of solid colors you change the color of the environment to make obstacles of the same color disappear and other obstacles of other colors appear.  While this is nothing new or innovating the main reason as to why I cannot recommend this game is because there is far too high of a level of luck involved verses actual skill.

There are several areas where the entire map will be one color with hazards and the platforms the same color so as you jump you leap into the air with a nothing but a color swatch for a frame of reference to be able to land in which you will most likely land in the platform and die.  You will die a lot from what I felt were unfair obstacles because they came down to luck and no real skill was needed to play through as far as I did until I stopped.

One of the most annoying examples of the luck aspect is eventually there are floating spinning spike wheels in the air and you have to change color to avoid them.  However they will be very close to each other and you have little time to actually know what the color you need is, in addition more often than not you may get one color right but the other hazard still within the same jump arc is another color and you will have no time to react so you fall take damage and probably die from falling off a platform.

This is a very simple concept that has been done a lot in the past; however there is so much to do with luck instead of skill I stopped after hour of constantly dying from unfair, and cheap situations.

It's is a neat mechanic that makes you think about how you will need to change the colors availble to progress through each level.

With that said this game is horrilbly executed. For starters, the art dirction fits the mechanics, but looks unpolished, like you would see in a flash game on miniclip. The music is annoying to say the least. Just a constant one minute loop. It isn't even catchy enough to get stuck in my head; just flat out forgetable.

Then there is the actual game play. From this point of veiw the game feels like it was made by an artist with a cool idea inted of an actual gamer or game designer. The hit boxes are way bigger than they should be. When changing backgound colors, objects disapper completely, so you might have a killer dog spawn next to you or die from having a platform pop up on top of your avatar. And worst of all, there are leaps of fate. Yes, you read that corectly. There are multiple points in the game where you jump as far as you can, change the color, and hope you land on something safe. I thought this was something we figured out in the SNES era.

So in short, a great concept that was horriblly executed. Funny thing is, a lot of the problems could have been fixed by improving the art design and having something there to signify where missing objects are. A dotted outline would have worked wonders. I do hope that I get to play another game with similar mechanics down the road. Playing this game made me remember just how creative games can get, and that the gaming scene has been getting stale lately. Even is the game play was poor, it was still a breath of freash air. So to all the game designers out there who read this, my future self included, remember to try and use new and fresh ideas in your game. Just make sure the game is fun as well.

This was a wonderful little game.  It felt very reminiscent of those harder levels from older platformers that you just can't seem to beat.  It took me roughly an hour and a half to beat it while dying over and over again.   Now here's a bit of a summary:

Pros:
That wonderful platformer feel
Innovative game mechanics (filters)
Engaging Introduction
Short and sweet
Sufficient challenge
Interesting music choice

Cons:
individual levels rely on trial and error on occasion (gears changing colors after a jump)
Surprise deaths (traps appear out of nowhere right near the exit of a particularly difficult level)
Story becomes less-engaging and grows vague as the game progresses (I was personally hoping for the story to blossom a bit further)
Hit-boxes (my biggest complaint, you're controlling a ragdoll half the time)
Jumping (occasionally couldn't double jump in the air after switching filters)

As someone who has formerly worked for a video game company, a bit of advice to the creators would be to clean up the hit boxes and jumping, and maintain patterns with color changing objects (e.g. maintain the same colors for surprise traps regardless of the current filter).  Seeing as though this game is free however, I can honestly say that it was a fun experience, and that I'll be recommending it to each of my friends.  I'll also be looking forward to any other games that these guys are working on.
It needs a better mechanic and better graphics, but It's free and can be fun.

Color Symphony is... okay. Given a bit of polish, maybe a little bit of difficulty added, a graphics overhaul, maybe change the story a little bit (read: start story from scratch), and this would be something I'd expect to see somewhere like Armor Games, New Grounds, or Miniclip. As it is, the game has a plot that doesn't make sense, graphics and story that try to come off as edgy (and fail, hence aforementioned graphics overhaul), and a soundtrack that doesn't suit the game. On the other hand, the controls are simple and easy to master for the most part, and the colour change concept is actually pretty clever.

However, it could have been implemented a little bit better. Enemies are reasonably easy to dodge, and if you hit one, you simply have to avoid it until your health regenerates, reducing the difficulty level. the erasure of multiple colours is confusing, and not needed after that tutorial level. There isn't a life system, so you can start from the start of the level as many times as you want. It also takes ages for the character to recover after being hit. Also, falling off screen is insta-death, which is annoying, as I feel like it should teleport you back to where you fell off, and reduce your health, although that would still be a slap on the wrist due to the regenerating health.

So, in other words, if I was developing the game, I would not have released it yet. The price of the game is an accurate reflection of how enjoyable it is (not very, due to rather quick boredom onset). As such, feel free to have a go, but don't be dissapointed when you get bored as I did.

Also, as a side note to the devs: I don't exactly know how you came up with the name of Color Symphony"

First to quickly note: My recommendation isn't that you don't play it, afterall it's completely free. It simply means whether or not I would go out of my way to recommend it and why. Of course you can overlook most of the problems I've experienced with this game since it's free and probably has little to no budget but they're still problems nonetheless which I feel shouldn't be overlooked in a review.

Color Symphony is a platforming puzzle game. In it, you switch between three colours to avoid or reveal like-coloured objects which can range from birds, dogs, spikes, platforms, doors and more. As you progress from door to door, the levels become harder and more complicated.

In general, it's a great concept that shines at the start. As you progress though, the limitations begin to show and, along with poor physics and collision detection, turns enjoyment into frustration. The cause can be any of the following and more:

Off-camera platforms which can only be seen by switching colors in mid-air and risking your life.
Enemies which are probably right on top of you which you can't see but are the same color as the thing you need to reach to progress.
Dying on spikes without visually touching them because their hit boxes are larger than their sprites.
Colliding against parts of the background which aren't in fact background (caused by the monotone-ish colour pallette).
Trying to measure distance for percision landing when there's nothing on camera to relate with
Once you die, you start back at the entrance to the level, which is forgiving at first but eventually as the levels become longer and the whole game becomes trial and error it becomes necessary as no hints are given as to what to expect beforehand.

As far as I played there was only one music track. Though it's a good track, being the only one in the game, it gets repetitive. Visually, everything is plain and generic with random props placed here and there in the background but, like the music, there's no variety and it gets boring fast. The visuals to however give the feeling of being in a void which is likely what the game is going for.

So to summarise, Color Symphony is a great concept which shines in its simplicity but gradually becomes more and more unfair and frustrating as it progresses.

I understand a lot of people are liking this game, and I feel like I would too. So let's start with what I liked about the game.

It's a platformer. Honestly, I just love platformers, and puzzle games excite me when I play them because I feel smart about solving the puzzle, and satisfaction literally washes over me as I beat a hard level.

The music was actually pretty nice to listen to, although it felt like it was just one song looping, it's a decent melody to follow while you're traversing this world.

The concept, as I'll state later as I get more into this, is incredibly fascinating and I really love the idea of manipulating colors to create platforms or make them disappear, and it's not just platforms; everything is made up of colors, specifically Blue, Green, and White. To play the game, you change the color scheme of the background to, as I said, make platforms and other things appear that are a different color of the background. A bird is one of the enemies in the game; it could either be Blue, Green, or White, and whatever color the background is, that bird will either appear as it is a different color, or it will not exist if you change the background to the same color as the bird. This, to me, is an incredibly innovative concept and, while not the most impressive, still pretty nice that someone even thought of this.

I did just call the concept a gimmick and, well, it's working. I'd be hooked if... there weren't some blaring problems. Now let's get to the parts I don't like.

I could not stand to play this game for more than 10 minutes at the most. It's going to take a lot of reworking to be considered a good game.

Right now, it's an amazing concept performed incredibly poorly. I might not be a game designer, but I know quite a bit of what it takes to make a good game, and the only thing good about Color Symphony is the concept, the music, and the level design(at least most of the time, but then again most of the levels I've played fabulously incorporated the controls of this game, no matter how much this game frustrates me); and yet, the controls are horrible.

The jump is fixed, which is a problem, especially when the boxes that determine if you're standing on a platform are terrible, as I've found myself to be stuck on the side of a platform, unable to jump or walk, and having to change the color and fall to my death.

In quite possibly every platformer, you'd control the height of your jump the longer you held down the jump button. I feel like a lot of this game would be made bearable if you could at least do that, among the many other things that need to be reworked, such as some of the level designs. While I said that they were great and that they incorporated the original intention of this game nicely, some of the levels, while beatable, didn't take much thought. What it did take, was changing the color multiple times to see if there's a platform, only to find a bird literally dive bombing you from inches away, a dog sitting right next to you and immediately biting you, and so on.

Another problem with the jump is the double jump feature. While it is pretty cool and sometimes saves you from when you would have taken a hit or died, if you wait too long on your initial jump, you lose the ability to jump a second time. Again, if you could double jump whenever was needed and not on a timer of some sort, the controls would be much more tolerated.

You can only take about 3 hits from absolutely anything in this game, and while you do regenerate your health, it takes way too long. I feel like that a part of the game is pulled away because you're so focused on regenerating health just so you can take another hit, meanwhile you have to change colors because a bird is coming for you and it's the same color of the platform you're standing on. If you change colors, you'll fall, possibly to your death. If you jump, it'll just fly vertically and attack you anyway. This needs to be reworked and thought over.

While I enjoyed this game, the simplicity of the controls mixed with the complexity of the level design was beautiful, and the music was nice, this is just too far from being a good game. I hope there's a big update on this game that the developer is working on, because I'd honestly love to play this game all the way through. It's just too much of a hassle to play at the moment.

That being said, I don't recommend this game AT THIS POINT IN TIME. If there's a big update changing at least the things I complained about in this review, I know I'm giving this game a solid 8/10.

reviewText:
I understand a lot of people are liking this game, and I feel like I would too. So let's start with what I liked about the game.

It's a platformer. Honestly, I just love platformers, and puzzle games excite me when I play them because I feel smart about solving the puzzle, and satisfaction literally washes over me as I beat a hard level.

The music was actually pretty nice to listen to, although it felt like it was just one song looping, it's a decent melody to follow while you're traversing this world.

The concept, as I'll state later as I get more into this, is incredibly fascinating and I really love the idea of manipulating colors to create platforms or make them disappear, and it's not just platforms; everything is made up of colors, specifically Blue, Green, and White. To play the game, you change the color scheme of the background to, as I said, make platforms and other things appear that are a different color of the background. A bird is one of the enemies in the game; it could either be Blue, Green, or White, and whatever color the background is, that bird will either appear as it is a different color, or it will not exist if you change the background to the same color as the bird. This, to me, is an incredibly innovative concept and, while not the most impressive, still pretty nice that someone even thought of this.

I did just call the concept a gimmick and, well, it's working. I'd be hooked if... there weren't some blaring problems. Now let's get to the parts I don't like.

I could not stand to play this game for more than 10 minutes at the most. It's going to take a lot of reworking to be considered a good game.

Right now, it's an amazing concept performed incredibly poorly. I might not be a game designer, but I know quite a bit of what it takes to make a good game, and the only thing good about Color Symphony is the concept, the music, and the level design(at least most of the time, but then again most of the levels I've played fabulously incorporated the controls of this game, no matter how much this game frustrates me); and yet, the controls are horrible.

The jump is fixed, which is a problem, especially when the boxes that determine if you're standing on a platform are terrible, as I've found myself to be stuck on the side of a platform, unable to jump or walk, and having to change the color and fall to my death.

In quite possibly every platformer, you'd control the height of your jump the longer you held down the jump button. I feel like a lot of this game would be made bearable if you could at least do that, among the many other things that need to be reworked, such as some of the level designs. While I said that they were great and that they incorporated the original intention of this game nicely, some of the levels, while beatable, didn't take much thought. What it did take, was changing the color multiple times to see if there's a platform, only to find a bird literally dive bombing you from inches away, a dog sitting right next to you and immediately biting you, and so on.

Another problem with the jump is the double jump feature. While it is pretty cool and sometimes saves you from when you would have taken a hit or died, if you wait too long on your initial jump, you lose the ability to jump a second time. Again, if you could double jump whenever was needed and not on a timer of some sort, the controls would be much more tolerated.

You can only take about 3 hits from absolutely anything in this game, and while you do regenerate your health, it takes way too long. I feel like that a part of the game is pulled away because you're so focused on regenerating health just so you can take another hit, meanwhile you have to change colors because a bird is coming for you and it's the same color of the platform you're standing on. If you change colors, you'll fall, possibly to your death. If you jump, it'll just fly vertically and attack you anyway. This needs to be reworked and thought over.

While I enjoyed this game, the simplicity of the controls mixed with the complexity of the level design was beautiful, and the music was nice, this is just too far from being a good game. I hope there's a big update on this game that the developer is working on, because I'd honestly love to play this game all the way through. It's just too much of a hassle to play at the moment.

That being said, I don't recommend this game AT THIS POINT IN TIME. If there's a big update changing at least the things I complained about in this review, I know I'm giving this game a solid 8/10.

Color Symphony is an interesting puzzler where you platform throughout the 50 levels using your ability to change the world's 'color', You switch between cream, blue and green to get through the somewhat challenging puzzling levels. Along the way you will encounter, crows, dogs and cogs which are all trying to take you down in their spectrum of colours.

While the game is good and rather intuitive, it also suffers from messy hitbox detection, sometimes cogs or birds will hit you even though there is a gap between you. Some of the puzzles require you to completely guess the distance you travel, which will lead to many deaths. What is also aggravating is when you switch colours if any part of your body is midway through a newly 'appearing' platform you will die and have to restart the level again. Some of the later levels require a lot of precision jumps in enclosed areas which can mean this gets aggravating.

Overall it is a fun and pretty unique platformer, not too long as it's only an hour or two in length. Especially as it's free to play it's at least worth a go if you are looking for a quick puzzler.

Since people tend to only read the short versions on here, I will sum it up first with a 7/10. Buggy, but still fairly good.

The game is simple enough - avoid the traps by using a button to filter out a colour. Blue trap? Blue filter. Green trap? Green filter. Multiple traps in quick succession? Press the buttons fast and hope it responds. There seemed to be a cooldown mechanic in place, which was a little offputting in a high-speed puzzle. Then again, you have certain puzzles that have green red AND yellow traps in the same area. This is where you have to use a special bar to use all the filters at once, thereby leaving only black ink. Why not do that all the time? Simple - it has a recharge timer, takes away your HP. and you actually need to land on a specific colour most of the time... Or you can fall through a platform and randomly hit the end of a level. Yeah I did that on quite a few of the levels on accident. (and three times on purpose!)

The bugs. Oh, the bugs... I fell through platforms, instead of walking through (they were literally closer together than one of the characters' legs, but apparently that doesn't matter) and I clipped through more than half the buildings I walked towards. This became to such an extent that in the three times I mentioned above, I actually exploited the clipping mechanic to skip a puzzle simply because I couldn't walk to the next platform. I couldn't jump either, as there was a trap within the minimum jump height. So... I don't quite know what else to do in that situation, as I tried repeatedly to walk past it and failed. Oh and it was black ink - no failure of mechanics, just hitbox error. Again, for the sake of fairness it has to be said that the entire game was beatable. It wasn't gamebreakingly bad, just unintentionally frustrating to traverse.

On top of the platform bug, there was a more annoying issue with persistency. Some coloured traps remained in certain situations (Such as walking to a new level) on same coloured filters. (ie. Yellow spike, yellow filter) This was mostly avoidable as far as i'm concerned, as the game should have checked the filter in use upon loading the level. Although it was able to be fixed in relative safety, it was slightly redundant to have to swap colours to fix this. Maybe if you could have pressed the same filter button to refresh itself that would have been better? Something for the Dev to look into for the sequel, if they haven't done that already.

This game had its fair share of ups and downs, and to be honest if it wasn't free I probably wouldn't have finished it. As daft as it sounds, I figured since the dev had the decency to post this game then I might as well finish it. I don't know if it is because I played the game in stages, but the end seemed to hit me faster than I expected. I finished the game in 1.9 Hours. That includes standing there annoyed at my character for clipping through a platform one time too many, going from my computer and making a cup of tea, getting a phone call, having said phone call, going back to the computer, realising the game was still on, and turning it off for about a month. I actually only managed to play the 1.9 hours over about three or four sittings, but that was mostly because I had other things to do. But, in the games defence I picked the game up and carried right on where I left off each time. It wasn't the fact it was frustrating, I simply forgot about it...

And speaking of forgetting, I don't quite know if the narrative was supposed to be an actual story, but it seemed very bland. White text on a yellow background (to avoid yellow trap) was hard to read, it didn't seem like it was there for any particular reason. It felt a little vague, as if lost in translation somehow. Not saying it was a bad thing, it just didn't seem to serve any purpose. It didn't move me, it didn't leave any lasting impression... It was just... there? *shrugs*

So, to cut a long story short i'll put a basic pro-con style thing here randomly for the heck of it, eh?

PRO:
The game was FREE. Can't get fairer than that in my opinion.
It was a playable game - even went as far as having an ending.
The mechanics are extremely easy to pick up, highly understandable.
The intentional frustration is very real, but not overly so. Challenge, not trials.

Balanced: The artwork was great, but the animation made it feel cheap. Kinda evens out.

CON:
The buggy platforms
The buggy filters
Some parts felt improperly paced
